BE11:15am

While we are conscious that this represents just the first quarter of Plus500's fiscal year, excepting a major reversal in current volatility trends, client behaviour or achieving material P&L gains, our current FY19 revenue forecast of $377.8m appears unachievable. We believe material downward revisions to consensus revenue for FY19, which is currently $445.8m per Bloomberg (18% ahead of our forecast), must follow.
• On our current forecasts, Plus500 trades at 7.3x CY19 P/E rising to 7.9x and yields 8.3% CY19 falling to 7.6%.
• Reiterate conviction SELL.

BE11:16am

They were sellers. Everyone else was buyers. No longer.

Berenberg:

red they were a sell when regs came in a year ago. anything after a bit late.
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Tough quarter demonstrates lack of visibility: In the first three months of
2019 Plus500 generated revenues of just $54m. This compares with our
prior forecast of $113m and to $155m in Q4 2018. Lower volatility and rising markets made trading conditions difficult, as was reported by peers IG and CMC. Unfortunately, while conditions could improve and extrapolating from a single quarter is dangerous, visibility is low and market losses are large. It is also difficult to separate the impact of markets and the regulatory restrictions on retail client trading. Plus500 does appear to be moving quickly to diversify revenues outside the EEA, where it earned 54% in Q1 compared with 60% in Q4. While positive in the short run, we also note that other important regulators are following ESMA’s example. For instance, the Australian regulator, ASIC, was recently granted powers of intervention and has moved more quickly than we had anticipated. This
week it requested data from firms operating in Australia. Given the lack of
visibility of revenues and signs that regulators will continue to target the
sector, we downgrade Plus500 to Hold until there is further clarity on what sustainable performance looks like.

BE11:18am

On valuation, shares on 8.5x downgraded Dec’19 earnings. On downgraded forecasts the business still delivers an EBITDA margin of 47% in FY19, ahead of others in the sector, with margins of c27%
given the low fixed cost base. Plus500 is a predominantly digital marketing business that relies on retail client acquisition. Its model is highly cash-generative with no costs from hedging. Concerns remain in the longer-term sustainability of the business (for example, the Australian regulator could potentially review this area and bring in similar rules to those in Asia and Europe). We place our recommendation and target price under review given the likely negative share price response.

BE11:23am

A low volatility quarter combined with clients making money (pre spreads) to mean very weak Q1 revenues at a third of the level of Q4, however new customer numbers are good, and spread revenue ARPU only down 14% on Q4. The $28m of client P&L takes 6% off our revenue estimate, and then it was a very weak quarter anyway. We take Q2-Q4 estimates down 7% (lower ARPU assumption) and end up with 2019 revenues 18% lower and EPS 26% lower. We still believe this company will continue to take share and to make great returns, so use 10x this year as a price target, or £10. Note 32% of the market cap in net cash by the year end. Lots of options, and an 8% yield while you wait.

BE11:27am

We do not think GoCompare would be bought by another PCW website such as Moneysupermarket.com or CompareTheMarket, although there may be an opportunity to be merged with a smaller player such as confused.com, due to likely regulatory concerns on competition grounds. However, we do see two potential groups of buyers. The first would be private equity groups who may be interested in the information that GoCompare holds and its WeFlip technology and, secondly, classified portal groups in the automotive and / or property space who may see a PCW service as a useful adjunct to their main offering. This is the strategy that ZPG pursued when it bought uSwitch, as did Scout24 (in a slightly different guise, focusing on consumer loans) in Germany when they bought Finanzcheck.de. Possible candidates who could be interested are AutoTrader but also the likes of eBay and CarGurus, who have been buying up UK classified automotive sites.

BE11:30am

Though of course, any firm interest at this point would lead to questions about timings, given Sir Peter Wood's decision to raise his stake just below the 30% mark earlier in the year.

BE11:48am

Chevron, the second-largest US oil and gas company, has agreed a $50bn deal to buy Anadarko Petroleum, one of the country’s leading independent producers, in the most significant move towards consolidation in the industry in the period of weaker oil prices that began in 2014.

The deal will strengthen Chevron’s position in US shale oil production in the Permian Basin of Texas and New Mexico, which it has been betting on as a strategic priority for expansion. It also brings the group more assets in deep water oil and liquefied natural gas, including Anadarko’s important new development in Mozambique.

The acquisition is expected to deliver cost and capital savings worth $2bn a year.

BE11:56am

Yesterday evening Entertainment One announced the acquisition of
Audio Network, one of the world’s largest creators and publishers of
music for use in the film and television industry, for a total consideration
of £178m. We see this acquisition as a sensible move with the combined
business creating further scale for eOne's established Music business and
additional synergies in eOne's content operations. At 15x LTM
EV/EBITDA, this acquisition looks attractive and should be earnings
accretive in the first year (2020E) on our estimates.

CS1 @1st Lt. :any idea of the mark up on pet food?
BE11:57am

The asset – a nice addition for eOne’s Music portfolio. Audio
Networks derives revenues from music licensing, approximately 60%
of revenues are subscription based. While UK based, the business
generates publishing revenues in 30+ territories with 70% of
revenues generated outside the UK and the financials look attractive -
Audio Network’s revenue grew +13% yoy to £29m and EBITDA
grew +22% yoy to £11m in FY18. Importantly, the key management
team of Audio Network including co-founder Andrew Sunnucks and
CEO Robb Smith will join the senior management team of eOne’s
Music business.

BE11:57am

So it does incidental music? Right?

11:57 am
BE11:57am

The company raised approximately £191m to fund the aggregate
consideration of £178m, transaction fees and expenses and to provide
balance sheet flexibility for future bolt-on acquisitions and general
corporate purposes. The acquisition was financed through £50m of
debt, £11m of eOne shares issued to Audio Network’s key
management and a £130m equity placing (the company yesterday
placed 28.9m new shares at 450p/share with additional finance from
£50m in debt).

In our recent detailed note on eOne, Peppa and PJ continue their
global adventure – stay OW, we flagged eOne as the top pick in
the Media Smid space driven by continuously strong momentum in
the international rollout of its Family brands. Our price target is 655p
while we highlight that our blue sky scenario offers a further
90p/share if the adoption of both Peppa and PJ proves to be more
successful than anticipated in the U.S. and China.

Alpha Male On PLUS: if avg leverage/customer fell from 15x to 3x, than assuming PLUS charges a spread (e.g. 10 bps), then their revenues would simple fall by 80% based on that maths. And that won't change anytime soon. Combine with rising ARCU, you get a gross profit of say 28m for Q1. Q2 last year was quiet, so assume similar: 56m H1 gp. But subtract SG&A of ~70m and you have a loss-making company. £180m cash on bal, sure, but if the business model is broken, how do you cut costs? imagine already pretty lean. Party's over?
